Award.AwardTitle: Genome Repatterning Underlying the Co-evolution of Diploid Number and Gender Determination in Turtles

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Gender is determined by genetic constitution in most animals (as by sex XX/XY chromosomes in humans, or ZZ/ZW in birds), and by environmental temperature (TSD) in others, including turtles. Notably, turtle lineages that underwent a transition in the gender-determining mechanism show a 20-fold increase in the rate of evolution of chromosome number, but it is unclear why or how these traits are associated. This project represents the first step to elucidate the functional link between these two traits by testing the hypothesis that chromosomal rearrangements disrupt the location and consequently the regulation of genes controlling sexual development, which in turn cause the transition between gender-determining mechanisms among turtles. By combining molecular cytogenetics, transcriptomics, bioinformatics and phylogenetic analyses, this project will reconstruct the organization of the ancestral turtle genome; characterize the chromosomal rearrangements that have taken place among turtles over 210 million years of turtle evolution; and build mechanistic hypotheses about the critical elements in the regulatory network of sexual development that underlie transitions in gender-determining mechanisms in turtles for further study. This project proposes a novel hypothesis about the relationship of genome evolution over large spans of time and gender determination, which if true, could transform our understanding of the mechanism by which gender determination evolves.

Broader Impacts
The educational activities of this project will help integrate undergraduate discovery-based learning and broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in biology by training students and their mentors; by engaging women and minorities through outreach activities; and by strengthening the PI's qualifications as role model for underrepresented groups.

OUTCOMES

 

Nicole Valenzuela (PI)

 

MCB  1244355

 Genome Repatterning Underlying the Co-evolution of Diploid Number and Gender Determination in Turtles

 Rationale: — Sex is determined by genetic constitution (GSD) in most animals (as by sex XX/XY chromosomes in humans, or ZZ/ZW in birds), and by environmental temperature (TSD) in others, including turtles. Notably, turtle lineages that underwent a transition in the sex-determining mechanism show a 20-fold increase in the rate of evolution of chromosome number, but it is unclear why or how these traits are associated. This project represents the first step to elucidate the functional link between these two traits by testing the hypothesis that chromosomal rearrangements disrupt the location and consequently the regulation of genes controlling sexual development, which in turn cause the transition between sex-determining mechanisms among turtles.

 Results: — Numerous cases were detected of chromosomes that broke apart or fused together during turtle evolution leading to the increase or decrease in chromosome number, as well as inversions in the order of genes within chromosomes among lineages. Some chromosomal rearrangements partially explain the changes in chromosome number during transitions in sex determination, and some involve genes governing sexual development and are located in sex chromosomes that evolved during transitions from TSD to GSD, whereas others are independent of changes in sex determination. Results indicate that multiple ancestral autosomes have become sex chromosomes during independent GSD evolution events in various turtle lineages, some repeatedly. Notably, several of these sex chromosomes potentially derive from one or two ancestral proto-sex chromosomes, indicating that some genomic regions are better suited for this role. The youngest sex chromosome system was discovered in two turtle species, one critically-endangered. Data obtained here is currently under analysis to reconstruct the ancestral turtle karyotype. Molecular evolution of genes involved in sexual development appears accelerated in turtle lineages were shifts in sex determination took place. Further, the location of genes in sex chromosomes or autosomes (chromosomes that are not sex chromosomes) also affects the rate of molecular evolution. The full composition of the gene network underlying gonadal formation and its response to temperature was elucidated in TSD and GSD turtles. Genomic resources for turtles were greatly increased and improved, enhancing some turtle species as emerging models to study ecology, evolution, and human health. Sex diagnostic methods were developed for turtles that are applicable to other taxa and that can detect other types of sexual dimorphism. Results were disseminated at national and international scientific conferences, and have been published in peer-review journals.

 Broader Significance and Scientific Importance: — Results allowed building mechanistic hypotheses about the critical elements in the regulatory network of sexual development that underlie transitions in sex-determining mechanisms in turtles for further study, and will enable the reconstruction of the ancestral turtle karyotype to better explain the causes and consequences of genome evolution in vertebrates. Educational Activities: This project provided research opportunities for 8 undergraduate students, 5 graduate students, 11 rotation students, and 2 postdocs. Additionally, one graduate student worked with a middle-school science teacher to develop and implement curricular material thus enhancing K-12 education.  Societal impact: Results have implications for the conservation of turtles in the face of environmental change.
